translated: The Path of Discrimination
The Chapter on Wisdom

original: 3.10. Mātikākathā🔽Nicchāto, mokkho vimokkho, vijjāvimutti, adhisīlaṁ, adhicittaṁ, adhipaññā, passaddhi,
analyzed: mātikā kathā  nicchātaḥ mokkhaḥ vimokkhaḥ vijjā vimutti adhi sīla adhi citta adhi paññā passaddhi
translated: The Exposition of the Mātikā🔽“Disenchantment, escape, liberation, wisdom-liberation, higher virtue, higher consciousness, higher wisdom, serenity,

original: ñāṇaṁ, dassanaṁ, visuddhi, nekkhammaṁ, nissaraṇaṁ, paviveko, vosaggo, cariyā, jhānavimokkho,
analyzed: ñāṇa dassana visuddhi nekkhamma nissaraṇa pavivekaḥ vosaggaḥ cariyā jhāna vimokkho
translated: knowledge, insight, purification, renunciation, escape, seclusion, relinquishment, practice, jhāna-liberation,
development, resolution, life.”

original: Nicchātoti nekkhammena kāmacchandato nicchāto, abyāpādena byāpādato nicchāto …pe…
analyzed: nicchātaḥ ti nekkhammena kāmacchandataḥ nicchātaḥ abyāpādena byāpādataḥ nicchātaḥ pe
translated: “Disenchantment”: through renunciation one is disenchanted with sensual desire; through non-ill will one is disenchanted with ill will; …
through the first jhāna one is disenchanted with the hindrances; …
through the path of arahantship one is disenchanted with all defilements.

analyzed: mokkhaḥ vimokkhaḥ ti nekkhammena kāmacchandataḥ muccati iti
translated: “Escape, liberation”: through renunciation one escapes and is liberated from sensual desire;
escape, liberation.
Through non-ill will one escapes and is liberated from ill will;
escape, liberation. …
Through the first jhāna one escapes and is liberated from the hindrances;
escape, liberation. …

analyzed: arahatta maggena sabba kilesehi muccati iti
translated: Through the path of arahantship one escapes and is liberated from all defilements;
escape, liberation.

original: Vijjāvimuttīti nekkhammaṁ vijjatīti vijjā, kāmacchandato muccatīti vimutti.
analyzed: vijjā vimutti iti nekkhammam vijjati iti vijjā kāma chandataḥ muccati iti vimutti
translated: ‘Knowledge and freedom’: renunciation is knowledge; one is freed from sensual desire, thus it is freedom.
One who has knowledge is freed; one who is freed has knowledge.
Thus it is knowledge and freedom.

original: Abyāpādo vijjatīti vijjā, byāpādato vimuccatīti vimutti.
analyzed: a byāpādaḥ vijjati iti vijjā byāpādataḥ vimuccati iti vimutti
translated: Non-ill will is knowledge; one is freed from ill will, thus it is freedom.
One who has knowledge is freed; one who is freed has knowledge.
Thus it is knowledge and freedom.

original: arahattamaggo vijjatīti vijjā, sabbakilesehi muccatīti vimutti.
analyzed: arahatta maggaḥ vijjati iti vijjā sabba kilesehi muccati iti vimutti
translated: … The path of arahantship is knowledge; one is freed from all defilements, thus it is freedom.
One who has knowledge is freed; one who is freed has knowledge.
Thus it is knowledge and freedom.

original: Adhisīlaṁ adhicittaṁ adhipaññāti nekkhammena kāmacchandaṁ, saṁvaraṭṭhena sīlavisuddhi, avikkhepaṭṭhena cittavisuddhi, dassanaṭṭhena diṭṭhivisuddhi.
analyzed: adhisīlam adhicittam adhipaññāti nekkhammena kāma chanda savara ṭṭhena sīla visuddhi avikkhepa ṭṭhena citta visuddhi dassana ṭṭhena diṭṭhi visuddhi
translated: ‘High wisdom, high mind, high insight’: through renunciation, sensual desire is abandoned; purification of virtue is virtue as restraint; purification of mind is virtue as non-distraction; purification of view is virtue as seeing.

analyzed: yaḥ tattha savaraṭṭhaḥ ayam adhi sīla sikkhā
translated: The restraint aspect is the training in the higher virtue.

analyzed: yaḥ tattha a vikkhepa aṭṭhaḥ ayam adhi citta sikkhā
translated: The non-distraction aspect is the training in the higher mind.

analyzed: yaḥ tattha dassana ṭṭhaḥ ayam adhi paññā sikkhā
translated: The seeing aspect is the training in the higher understanding.

analyzed: a byāpādena byāpādam sa varaṭṭhena sīla visuddhi pe
translated: Through non-ill will, ill will is abandoned; purification of virtue is virtue as restraint …

original: arahattamaggena sabbakilese saṁvaraṭṭhena sīlavisuddhi, avikkhepaṭṭhena cittavisuddhi.
analyzed: arahatta maggena sabba kilese savara ṭṭhena sīla visuddhi avikkhepa ṭṭhena citta visuddhi
translated: With the path of Arahantship, purification of virtue is through restraint, purification of cognizance is through non-distraction,

original: Dassanaṭṭhena diṭṭhivisuddhi.🔽Yo tattha saṁvaraṭṭho, ayaṁ adhisīlasikkhā.
analyzed: dassana aṭṭhena  yaḥ tattha savaraṭṭhaḥ ayam adhi sīla sikkhā
translated: and purification of view is through seeing.🔽The restraint here is training in the higher virtue.

analyzed: yaḥ tattha a vikkhepa aṭṭhaḥ ayam adhi citta sikkhā
translated: The non-distraction here is training in the higher cognizance.

analyzed: yaḥ tattha dassana ṭṭhaḥ ayam adhi paññā sikkhā
translated: The seeing here is training in the higher understanding.

original: Passaddhīti nekkhammena kāmacchandaṁ paṭippassambheti, abyāpādena byāpādaṁ paṭippassambheti …pe…
analyzed: passaddhi iti nekkhammena kāmacchandam paṭippassambheti abyāpādena byāpādam paṭippassambheti pe
translated: ‘Tranquillization’: through renunciation he tranquillizes lust, through non-ill-will he tranquillizes ill-will, …
through the path of Arahantship he tranquillizes all defilements.

original: Ñāṇanti kāmacchandassa pahīnattā nekkhammaṁ ñātaṭṭhena ñāṇaṁ;
analyzed: ñāṇan ti kāmacchandassa pahīna ttā nekkhammam ñāta ṭṭhena ñāṇa
translated: ‘Knowledge’: because lust is abandoned, renunciation is knowledge in the sense of known.

analyzed: byāpādassa pahīna ttā abyāpādaḥ ñāta ṭṭhena ñāṇam pe
translated: Because ill-will is abandoned, non-ill-will is knowledge in the sense of known. …

original: sabbakilesānaṁ pahīnattā arahattamaggo ñātaṭṭhena ñāṇaṁ.🔽Dassananti kāmacchandassa pahīnattā nekkhammaṁ diṭṭhattā dassanaṁ.
analyzed: sabba kilesānam pahīna ttā arahatta maggo ñāta ṭṭhena ñāṇa  dassanam ti kāmacchandassa pahīna ttā nekkhammam diṭṭha ttā dassana
translated: Because all defilements are abandoned, the path of Arahantship is knowledge in the sense of known.🔽‘Seeing’: because lust is abandoned, renunciation is seeing in the sense of seen.

analyzed: byāpādassa pahīna ttā a byāpādaḥ diṭṭha ttā dassanam pe
translated: Because ill-will is abandoned, non-ill-will is seeing in the sense of seen. …

analyzed: sabba kilesānam pahīna ttā arahatta maggo diṭṭha ttā dassana
translated: The path of arahatship is the seeing because of the seeing of the destruction of all defilements.

analyzed: visuddhi iti kāmacchandam pajahantaḥ nekkhammena visujjhati
translated: Purification: by abandoning sensual desire one is purified by renunciation.

analyzed: byāpādam pajahantaḥ a byāpādena visujjhati pe
translated: By abandoning ill will one is purified by non-ill will …

original: sabbakilese pajahanto arahattamaggena visujjhati.🔽Nekkhammanti kāmānametaṁ nissaraṇaṁ, yadidaṁ nekkhammaṁ.
analyzed: sabba kilese pajahantaḥ arahatta maggena visujjhati  nekkhammanti kāmānam etam nissaraṇa yat idam nekkhamma
translated: by abandoning all defilements one is purified by the path of arahatship.🔽Renunciation: this is the escape from sensual desires, namely renunciation.
This is the escape from materiality, namely the immaterial.

original: Yaṁ kho pana kiñci bhūtaṁ saṅkhataṁ paṭiccasamuppannaṁ, nirodho tassa nekkhammaṁ.
analyzed: yam kho pana kiñci bhūtam saṅkhatam paṭiccasamuppanna nirodho tassa nekkhamma
translated: And whatever is formed, caused, dependently arisen, its cessation is renunciation.
Non-ill will is the renunciation of ill will.
The perception of light is the renunciation of stiffness and torpor …
The path of arahatship is the renunciation of all defilements.

analyzed: nissaraṇam ti kāmānam etam nissaraṇa yat idam nekkhamma
translated: Escape: this is the escape from sensual desires, namely renunciation.
This is the escape from materiality, namely the immaterial.

original: Yaṁ kho pana kiñci bhūtaṁ saṅkhataṁ paṭiccasamuppannaṁ, nirodho tassa nissaraṇaṁ.
analyzed: yam kho pana kiñci bhūtam saṅkhatam paṭiccasamuppanna nirodho tassa nissaraṇa
translated: And whatever is formed, caused, dependently arisen, its cessation is the escape.
Renunciation is the escape from sensual desire.
Good will is the escape from ill will …
The path of arahantship is the escape from all defilements.

analyzed: paviveko ti kāmacchandassa nekkhammaṃ paviveko pe
translated: Renunciation is the seclusion from sensual desire …

original: sabbakilesānaṁ arahattamaggo paviveko.🔽Vosaggoti nekkhammena kāmacchandaṁ vosajjatīti—
analyzed: sabba kilesānam arahatta maggo paviveko  vosaggaḥ ti nekkhammena kāmacchandam vosajjati iti
translated: The path of arahantship is the seclusion from all defilements.🔽‘Giving up’: through renunciation one gives up sensual desire …

analyzed: vosaggaḥ  a byāpādena byāpādam vosajjati iti
translated: giving up is …🔽through good will one gives up ill will …
giving up is …

analyzed: arahatta maggena sabba kilese vosajjati iti
translated: through the path of arahantship one gives up all defilements.
Giving up is …

analyzed: cariyā ati kāmacchandam pajahantaḥ nekkhammena carati
translated: ‘Conduct’: one who abandons sensual desire conducts himself with renunciation.
One who abandons ill will conducts himself with good will …

original: sabbakilese pajahanto arahattamaggena carati.🔽Jhānavimokkhoti nekkhammaṁ jhāyatīti—🔽jhānaṁ.
analyzed: sabba kilese pajahantaḥ arahatta maggena carati  jhāna vimokkhaḥ ti nekkhammam jhāyati iti  jhāna
translated: one who abandons all defilements conducts himself with the path of arahantship.🔽‘Absorption and emancipation’: one who absorbs sensual desire absorbs it with renunciation.
Absorption is …🔽one who burns up sensual desire burns it up with renunciation.

analyzed: jhāna  jhāyantaḥ muccati iti  jhāna vimokkho  jhāpentaḥ muccati iti
translated: Absorption is …🔽one who is emancipated by absorbing burns up by absorbing.
Absorption and emancipation is …🔽‘Absorbing’ are ideas.
‘Burning up’ are defilements.

analyzed: jhāte ca jhāpe ca jānāti iti
translated: He knows what is burnt and what is burning:
he is a burner-up of what is burnt.
Non-ill will burns: it is a burning.
It burns away ill will:
it is a burning. …
Light perception burns:
it is a burning.
Sloth and torpor burn:
it is a burning. …
The path of arahatship burns:
it is a burning.
It burns away all the defilements:
it is a burning.
One is liberated by burning:
it is a liberation by burning.
One is liberated by burning away:
it is a liberation by burning.
Burning:
it is ideas.
Burning away:
it is defilements.

analyzed: jhāte ca jhāpe ca jānāti iti
translated: He knows what is burnt and what is burning:
he is a burner-up of what is burnt.

original: Bhāvanā adhiṭṭhānaṁ jīvitanti kāmacchandaṁ pajahanto nekkhammaṁ bhāvetīti—
analyzed: bhāvanā adhiṭṭhānam jīvitanti kāmacchandam pajahantaḥ nekkhammam bhāveti iti
translated: He is one who has developed the profitable in that he is abandoning sensual desire by means of renunciation,

analyzed: bhāvanā sampannaḥ  nekkhamma vasena cittam adhiṭṭhāti iti
translated: he is one perfected in development.🔽He is one who has undertaken in that he has undertaken the mind by means of renunciation,

original: adhiṭṭhānasampanno.🔽Svāyaṁ evaṁ bhāvanāsampanno adhiṭṭhānasampanno samaṁ jīvati, no visamaṁ;🔽sammā jīvati, no micchā;
analyzed: adhiṭṭhāna sampannaḥ  evam bhāvanā sampannaḥ adhiṭṭhāna sampanno samam jīvati no  sammā jīvati na u micchā
translated: he is one perfected in undertaking.🔽He lives evenly, not unevenly,🔽he lives rightly, not wrongly,
he lives purely, not impurely:
he is one perfected in livelihood.

original: Svāyaṁ evaṁ bhāvanāsampanno adhiṭṭhānasampanno ājīvasampanno yaññadeva parisaṁ upasaṅkamati—
analyzed: svāyam evam bhāvanā sampannaḥ adhiṭṭhāna sampannaḥ ājīva sampannaḥ yaññat eva parisam upasaṅkamati
translated: When someone has developed these things, has established them well within themselves, and has perfected his livelihood, then whatever assembly he approaches—

original: yadi khattiyaparisaṁ yadi brāhmaṇaparisaṁ yadi gahapatiparisaṁ yadi samaṇaparisaṁ—
analyzed: yadi khattiya parisam yadi brāhmaṇa parisam yadi gahapati parisam yadi samaṇa parisa
translated: whether of nobles, brahmins, householders, or contemplatives—
he approaches it with confidence and without fear.
Why is that?

original: Tathā hi so bhāvanāsampanno adhiṭṭhānasampanno ājīvasampanno.
analyzed: tathā hi so bhāvanā sampannaḥ adhiṭṭhāna sampannaḥ ājīva sampannaḥ
translated: Because he has developed these things, has established them well within himself, and has perfected his livelihood.

analyzed: byāpādam pajahantaḥ a byāpādam bhāveti iti  bhāvanā sampannaḥ pe
translated: ‘Abandoning ill will, he develops a mind without ill will.’🔽He has developed these things, has established them well within himself, and has perfected his livelihood.

original: thinamiddhaṁ pajahanto ālokasaññaṁ bhāvetīti—🔽bhāvanāsampanno …pe…🔽uddhaccaṁ pajahanto avikkhepaṁ bhāvetīti—
analyzed: thinam iddham pajahantaḥ āloka saññam bhāveti iti  bhāvanā sampannaḥ pe  uddhaccam pajahantaḥ avikkhepam bhāveti iti
translated: ‘Abandoning dullness and drowsiness, he develops the perception of light.’🔽He has developed these things, has established them well within himself, and has perfected his livelihood.

analyzed: bhāvanā sampannaḥ pe  vicikiccham pajahantaḥ dhamma vavatthānam bhāveti iti
translated: ‘Abandoning restlessness and anxiety, he develops a mind free from restlessness.’🔽He has developed these things, has established them well within himself, and has perfected his livelihood.

analyzed: bhāvanā sampannaḥ pe  avijjam pajahantaḥ vijjam bhāveti iti  bhāvanā sampannaḥ pe
translated: ‘Abandoning doubt, he develops the discernment of principles.’🔽He has developed these things, has established them well within himself, and has perfected his livelihood.🔽‘Abandoning ignorance, he develops knowledge.’
He has developed these things, has established them well within himself, and has perfected his livelihood.
‘Abandoning discontent, he develops contentment.’🔽He has developed these things, has established them well within himself, and has perfected his livelihood.

analyzed: nīvaraṇe pajahantaḥ paṭhamam jhānam bhāveti iti
translated: When he abandons the hindrances, he develops the first jhāna.
He is accomplished in development.

analyzed: sabba kilese pajahantaḥ arahatta maggam bhāveti iti
translated: When he abandons all defilements, he develops the path to Arahantship.
He is accomplished in development.

analyzed: arahatta magga vasena cittam adhiṭṭhāti iti
translated: He resolves his mind on the path to Arahantship.

original: adhiṭṭhānasampanno.🔽Svāyaṁ evaṁ bhāvanāsampanno adhiṭṭhānasampanno samaṁ jīvati, no visamaṁ;🔽sammā jīvati, no micchā;
analyzed: adhiṭṭhāna sampannaḥ  evam bhāvanā sampannaḥ adhiṭṭhāna sampanno samam jīvati no  sammā jīvati na u micchā
translated: He is accomplished in resolution.🔽He lives in balance, not in imbalance;
he lives rightly, not wrongly;🔽he lives purely, not impurely.

original: ājīvasampanno.🔽Svāyaṁ evaṁ bhāvanāsampanno adhiṭṭhānasampanno ājīvasampanno yaññadeva parisaṁ upasaṅkamati—
analyzed: ājīva sampannaḥ  svāyam evam bhāvanā sampannaḥ adhiṭṭhāna sampannaḥ ājīva sampannaḥ yaññat eva parisam upasaṅkamati
translated: He is accomplished in livelihood.🔽He is accomplished in development, in resolution, and in livelihood. Whatever assembly he approaches—

original: yadi khattiyaparisaṁ yadi brāhmaṇaparisaṁ yadi gahapatiparisaṁ yadi samaṇaparisaṁ—
analyzed: yadi khattiya parisam yadi brāhmaṇa parisam yadi gahapati parisam yadi samaṇa parisa
translated: whether of nobles, brahmans, householders, or contemplatives—
he approaches it with confidence and assurance.
Why is that?

original: Tathā hi so bhāvanāsampanno adhiṭṭhānasampanno ājīvasampannoti.
analyzed: tathā hi saḥ bhāvanā sampannaḥ adhiṭṭhāna sampannaḥ ājīva sampannaḥ iti
translated: Because he is accomplished in development, in resolution, and in livelihood.

analyzed: mātikā kathā niṭṭhitā  paññā vaggo tatiyaḥ
translated: The exposition of the lists is finished.
The third chapter called “The Chapter of Wisdom”🔽The summary:
Understanding, success, penetration,
Seclusion, practice as the fifth;
Wondrous, on the head,
The foundations of mindfulness, insight;
In the third, the best of the sections on understanding,
And the ten in the matrix.
The Great Section, the Twin,
And the Understanding Section by name;
These are the three sections in this
Treatise on the Discriminations.

analyzed: ananta naya maggesu  gambhīraḥ sāgara upamaḥ  nabhañca tārakākiṇṇa
translated: In the paths of the infinite system,🔽Deep, like the ocean;🔽And the sky studded with stars,
Like a great lake that has burst its banks;
For the expounders, it is vast,
The light of knowledge for meditators.
The text of the Path of Discrimination is finished.
